div.p: ¶ An order / whych a Prince in battayll muste obserue, and kepe, yf he entende to subdewe, or passe thoroughe his enemyes landes.
☞{fleur-de-lys}☜

div.head: ¶ A necessare order to be obserued in battayll.

div.p: FYrst he must examin, whether hys cause be lawfull and iuste, for in a iuste cause: God shall assyste hym.
Item he must prouyde that he haue a sufficiente nomber of men and moneye redy for them.

Item he muste counsail, wyth the most wyse & experte mē of hys realme, of the weyght and daungers, that may fal: so that as farre as reason may leade him, he be not ignoraunte, what frute shall follow of hys bataill.
Item he muste prouyde that hys hoste lacke no vyttayles.

Itē he must see that he lacke no
engine and other thyng requyred to defende hym selfe or inuade hys ennemy.

Item that he haue capitaynes experte in warres the whych shall execute hys cōmaundement Item let hym be assuryd of hys owne cuntrey or he inuade hys enemy, and yf case require, sette it quyet or elles departe not.
Item lette hym leue behynde hym sūme noble and crusted man to order and yf nede be to subdew hys enemyes in hys absence and order them.
Item that the moste strongest fortresse be cōmytted to hys most trusty freyndes.

Item ye he oftentymes cōsulte & coūsiall wyth hys wyse & experte coūsiall that he may know what is moste expediēte to doo, and let
hym vse theyre counsaill.
Item when he entreth hys enemyes landes, he shall call hys hoste before hym yt he may know the number, and yf he fynde any vnable to battaile put him away.

Item that he haue no superfluous carryage, for ther of groweth greate dyspleasure, specially, when a prince intendeth shorte victory, and then let hys vyttayles be hys moost carryage wherin must be taken a good order, so that he haue thē with him or passe by such places wher it maibe had or els he wasshethe a stone, that is to saye, he laboureth in vaine.
Howe onely by customable vsage of dedes of armes the Romaynes had the victory of all other nations.

The olde custō to chose knightes
at .xvi. yere was age of to be perfete in theyr age and to the custome of warre.
Also a prince must dyligently consyder, whych be most pryncypal and most expert, & ouer that. what euery man in hys hoste is moost apte vnto.

For it is very perylous to set an vnexperte mā in aucthoryte: for diuers mē haue dyuerse wyttes, and as they be, they must be vsed. Some be able to rewie an hoste: Some. C. foremen, other a hundreth horsemē, some be good on horse, some be good on fote, other be good in felde or battail, other to inuade a castel, other to de fende it, other sodeynly on horse to inuade an hooste, otherwyfte on horsebacke to espye newes, other in rydyng, to compasse a felde
and note they re number, other apte to chose a mete or apte place for a felde, other be experte in bat taill, & naught whē they be at it, whose counsaill is not to be refused, other haue no experiēce, how be it they be valyaunt when they be put therto, other be both exper te and victoryous, other be able neyther to counsail defēde nor inuade, they be good at home. {quod} secta in vtilis. other be good in ingynes, other to make brydges & passages, other to espye they renemyes secretes, in dyssymuled habite, other to gyue coūsell and dyscusse ambassades, other mete for executiō of iustice, other me te to kepe a princes treasure, and other thynges of charge.

Item the fore warde of the battaill must be stronge aswell wyth
horsemen, as with footemen, and let there be put his capitaines of the valyaunste.
Item he muste consyder that hys felde be set to a aduauntage and accordynge therto the hoste must be ordered.

Item that he prouide, where hys hoste shall cōmodyously reste or he departe from whens he is and diligently let hym note the cūtry whether it be plain, hilly, moūtaynes or full of waters, & what straytes be therin.
Item yf he may, let hym haue it trewlye paynted or he enter: so that the daūgiers may be knowen and the horsemen may healpe the footemen in tyme of warre.

Itē let him prouide that his carriage trouble not his host, yf they be inuaded, wherfore let them be
conueyed by the one syde: prouyded that they be surely garded.
Item there must be pronysiō, that all artillary maye be surely caryed: for the losse of that is the perill of the hoste.
Itē that the explorators be sēt to espye the iourneys of the aduersaryes, and what vyttaylles they haue, with all other thinges by them intended.
Item that he take deliberation, yf he may get the frendeshyp of any greate man of hys enemyes counsayll, by corruption of money or otherwyse, by whom he may know the purpose of hys sayde enemyes.

Item that euery day, there be sent light horsemen to the aduersaries host to perceiue theyr purpose, lest they be sodēly inuaded,
and also to thentente he may inuade them vnprouyded yf the case so requyred. Requiruntur multi secreti et fideles.

Item yf he can perceyue that hys aduersary intende hasty battayle, let hym take hym selfe in a wayte, that he may prouyde hym in takyng of hys felde to his aduauntage, & put hym selfe shortcely in order.

Item yf he knowe any daungerous waye betwene hym and hys enemeis, he shall by wysdom and dilygence procede towarde that, vntyll he come wythin .iii. or. iiii. bowe shotes, and ther put hym selfe in order to inuade hys hoste.
Item he muste espye what artyllary hys enemies vse & what order they take.
Item euery country hath his maner of fyghtynge to there aduantage, and there enemyes cōfusyon.
Item he must beware of euery harde and dowtefull passage, except he haue leasure to cōuaye hys hoste or excepte necessyte cōpelle hym.
Item it is better to abyde the comming to a bataill, then to inuade, for the fyrst commers comōly lacke order.
Itē yf the enemyes ryde oute of order, and wander, inuade thē, for lacke of order shal destroy thē
Item yf thyn enemyes drawe to hostry of no strength and dysperse them selfe, then they be esylyer taken.

Item when the hoste draweth nere to the enemies, let the wardes
come night together for their better surcottes.
Item that footemen be on the one syde not mixte wyth horsemē, {quod} generaretur confusio.
Item in euery warde must be some wyth hand gunnes, crosbowes and other manuall ingyns, and likewyse in the latter warde, to put a syde the lyhgt horsemen.
Item yf he may let hym, prouyde that the sonne and wynde, be for him, specyally for duste, yf there be any.

Itē yf he be horsed, and strōger then hys enemy, let hym prouoke hym to open bataill in the playne felde, and yf hys footemē be myghtyer then hys enemyes horsemē, let hym take the aduaūtage of a streyght place.

Item when he inuadeth hys
enemy lette hys carriage be put, in the one syde & surely garded.
Item he shall put hys ingynes of battaill betwene him and hys enemyes and well defende them.

Item yf he be compelled to folowe hys enemye, and for default of vittaile to inuade therni, or yf he dreade lest hys hoste fortefy hys company, so yt he cannot escape, excepte he ouercome his hoste, let him study to breake hys felde, that is to say, let hym vexe thē wyth gonnes and other poyntes of warre, so yt they maye disorder them selfes.
Item a prince muste note the tyme and vse as it serueth hym.

Item when he is actually entered battail, hys host shall stāde styll in a clust, erand in no wyse
remoue frome the place, whatsoeuer he see, though he see his cōpany partely flee & partely slayne, and also though he see hys enemyes flee, for order make the and marreth all.

Item whē thou hast inuaded thyne enemyes wt the fore & hynder warde, let the myddell stande styffe and close to helpe bothe, as nede shall requyre, and whē both wardes haue well fought, let the myddell warde fyght, but for all that let, them not dysorder them selfe excepte compulsyon.
Item he must haue prouysion for passages of waters,
Itē before the batayl, a prince must see the order of his host, and reforme all thynges mysordered, and thys may not be forgotten.

Item he shal shew them, that
he wyll lyue and dye wyth them that day, and that besydes theyre perpetuall honour, he wyl neuer forget to honour & rewarde thē. additio. A and for thys let him see couragyous prynces orations, as Alexander, Catiline, wyth other infinite. &c.
Item he shal neyther magnifye hys enemy nor despyce hym but encorage hys capytaygnes, to kepe there order, & yf that they so doo, the victory wyll folowe.
Itē he shall practise that both his enemy and hys hoste, may alwaye thynke that more strength is commynge to hym.
Item that he see no robbyng, and that he commaūde hys captaines to see that obserued, payne of death.

Item that he execute indyfferently
iustice, and punyshe them, that cause debates.
Item when hys enemyes doo treate of peace, then let hym selfe lefte awayt. Propter pericula in hoe casu experta.

Item let no mā passe hys cūtry, and inuade an other, without nede require, excepte he see, howe he may returne wyth honour, or howe he may surely abyde there: it is but symplenes to goo vp and downe in a cn̄try, and to ryde farre in it, and harde it is to be longe sure in a cuntrey straung, and to returne wt honor, for in the tyme of Talbot .vl knyghtes of Englāde laied sege to ye towre of Roane, and whē they lacked that was necessary for theyr defence, therfore they loste it, & lyke thynges were done in at Britaine at
Vans where they loste all.
Item yf any tydynges come forthwyth, let them be herde, and folow thē, as the tyme shall serue
Item a prince, must be keping hys promyse, elles no man shall truste hym.
Item he muste study to haue the fauoure of the beste of the cūstrey, and he muste be iuste and egall.
Item a prince muste study to haue the freindeshyp of the cuntreis adioynyng, and let hym not haue, battaill wyth diuers at once, excepte he be compelled, for there is moche suttelty vsed.
Item in the day of the battaill he must haue aboute hym, a certen of the wysest & moost experte men, to kepe follow and coūsaill them.
Item he muste prouyde that hys enemyes espye not the number of hys hoste and the order of the same.

Item yf it fortune hym to lese a batayll or .ii. or to lese hys actillary, then pollicy is to resorte to some fortres, and there to call hys hoste togyther, & to refreshe them as nedethe and to get newe men, and to take peace yf he can, and in the meane tyme to make hys fortresse stronge, tyll he be able by some meanes to make bataill, and to haue all thynges rede therfore.
Item he shall sette hys tentes nyghe to hys enemies hoste that he may trouble and breake theyr aray.
Item he muste beware that he be not beseged.

Item he must beware that after one bataile lost, he begine not another forth wyth, excepte necessyte compell hym, for after a dystrage the hoste can not sodenely be apte to fyght, for woūdes and mornynges shall let them & theyr enemyes after vyctory, be more imboldet, how be it oftentymes, men thynke vpon dyspleasure to be reuēged and so for lacke of policy take fury rebuke and in thys maner Charles duke of Burgon was destroyed, wherfore set reasō before wyll, and begyn to thynke nothynge harde to perfourme.
Item yf thou wynne a batail or a forteresse of thyne enemies, pursew hym graciously, and suffer him neyther to reste nor to restable hys stregth, wysdom it is to folowe the aduauntage.
Item yf thou get a cuntry cōmitte it to some greate man, and lykewyse of forteresses, and let hym be well intreated, and lacke no moneye for suche men woulde be cherysshed.

div.head: ¶ The maner of besegyng a forteresse.
div.p: FYrst a Prince muste remēbre whether he haue sufficient mē to besege yt in .iii. diuers parties, & whether ouer that he haue men sufficyente for hys owne defence and moneye bothe.
Item he muste prouyde artyllary and vittayles necessary and let him well beware that his vittayll come not to hys enemyes handes, and this principall to be noted.
Item he muste espye some mā that knowethe the strengthe of the forteresse and thery counsell muste he vse.
Item he must espye how it be most easely taken where and hys hoste may beste set theyr felde for theyr assuerty.
Item that done set them in the forwarde that were before sente to espye the strengthe of the forteresse well furnysshed wyth archers, and dyggers and all other thynges.
Item let them cōme as nyghe to the walles as they can and so order them that they may reiecte theyre enemies dartes.

Item aboue all thynges prouide that nothyng may passe out or enter into the forteresse, for yf one gate be open it shall be neuer
euercome.
Item let one warde be euer redy to helpe the other as nede shal require.
Item the fyrste daye of besegyng the felde must be fortyfied.

Item mē must be sente to euery place to espye whether any rescue be intended .&c. and yf it so be let hym consyder there power and yf he see parell remowe hys hoste and hys artyllary lest he be inuaded in bothe sydes, & voyde to some sure forteresse, for ye tyme
Item yf he see his enemies of small power he maye set some to fyght wyth thē and other to kepe the sege.

Item whē the walles be broken fortyfy hys mē, and make an assawte, prouided that he leue behynde them both horsemen and
fotemen, to wythstāde hys backe enemyes for that not doynge the erle of Arminac loste by Sander a castell of Lumbardy.

Item yf he be put a backe in the fyrst conflicte let hym inuade assone as the daye folowyng, for vpon a vyctory oftentymes the opidanis be necligent, trustynge not sodeynly to be inuaded, by thys prouisyon many places and forteres hath ben optayned.
Item many other thynges be required how be it a prince muste specyally beware of treason and simulation.

div.head: ❧ Howe a Prince beseged shall order hym selfe.
div.p:
ABoue all thynge a Prynce must study aswel in tyme of peace as in warre be knowe
hys neyghbours myndes, and oftentymes to sēde orators to thē aswell to nourysshe loue as to knowe theyr good wyll.
Item yf he see by a Prynces ordinaūce that he intēdeth warre let hym streyngthe hys forteresse towardes that contry.
Itē let hym make some freinde in that Princes house by whō he may knowe what is intended.

Itē yf he be assurid yt the prince intedeth hym warre let hym prepare an hoste of as myghty men as hys money wyll suffer hym to doo, and yf he thynke hym suffycient to ouercom him, let hym folowe hys fortune and tarry hys enemie in the entre to hys contry or yf he maye in hys enemyes contrye.

Item yf he thynke hym selfe
vnsufficyente in men and money let hym fortify hys hedde places nexte to hys enemyes, and garde them wyth money.
Item yf there be moo forteresses then he maye furnysshe let them be take downe and all maner vyttayll be caryed frō thens, and the cuntry lefte bare.
Item let him haue good capitaygnes in hys Forteresses the whyche maye doo hys enemyes daylye dyspleasure and dysperse his hoste, as it was done at Mitz and other places.
Item horsemen must be prouided as it shalbe thought necessary to take the messengers, and then make prouision with order.
Ite yf such obstacles be purueyed for enemies they shal lytle preuayle.

div.head: ❧ How a forteresse shal be kept and howe they that be beseged shall order theyr selfe.
div.p: FYrste dygge vp the erthe to the heyght of the walles, for gonnes and other ingynes.

Item the bulwarkes must be fortefyed and he muste beware that the innar byldynges ioyne not to the walles for nygh to the walle inwardly muste be made a trenche to a good heyght so that yf the wall fayle the wall of erth may helpe.
Item he muste haue good capitaynes to order and visite hys watche of the walles and men experte.

Item crosbowes, būbardes, dykers, phisitiōs, surgeons, potticares,
wyth all other thynges necessarye.
Item he must haue one capitayne to order hys watches as nede shall require.
Item euery nyght the walles must be sene and an order set and kepte for there sure custody,
Item there muste be watche kepte nygh to the walles to helpe there kepers as nede shall require, and also to withstāde inwarde treason.
Item yf there be any noyse let euery mā go to there owne place for oftētimes such noyse is made, to maike men ronne together, whyle theyre enemyes inuade.
Item lette it be taken heade theyre whyles, that theyr waters be not poysoned.

Item when he shall inuade,
let hym well counsayll, and hys commodities foresene.
Item yf the walles be brokē, lette thē be amended forthe with, for feare of inuasion, as it was at the Rodes, whyles the Lorde was at masse.
Item let it euer be cōmoned, that more people shall cōme, to healpe to put them in better cōforte.
Item a prince muste be ware that theyre be noo murmure in the hooste and yf theyre be, that they be openlye punysshed.

Item yf the capitaine vnderstande, that any battaille is lost, or foreteresse taken, vnknowne vnto hys hooste, let that be kepte secrete, and lette hym euer shewe hys hooste, thynges of comforte and pleasure.
Item in the principal partes, muste be sette pryncypall men.
Item he muste haue gnydes, that knowe the countrye.
Item yf anye message come, lette him ponder, and repelye discusse yt, and be not ouer lyghte of credence.
Itē yf it be a countrye of hylles, waters, or of straytes, he muste haue the moo footemen.
Item when it is proceded in battaille, some wyse men stronge and sure, muste be leste behynde, leste they inuayde in ye inner parte of the battaylle.
Item let newe lockes of gaytes ofte be maide for feare of coūterfeytynge, and it muste be prouyded of sure kepers.

Item in the nyght, there must be sure watche, aboute, the yates
for daungers, that maye fall, as it was done at Arras.
Item there muste be made barrars, nyghe vnto the foreteresse for the defence of footemen, and the sauety othorsemen, and dyuerse other consyderations.
Itē the walles shall be strengthed wyth thornes, for shakinge.
Item prysoners must be well entreated, and yf thou take hym that is not trew vnto hys prince, punyshe hym forthe wythall.

Item yf any enemyes treate of delyueraunce, of theyr foreteresses heare it well, but be not lyghte of credence, for theyre be many souttelryes ymagined, and at Betynam many were by that meane destroyed.

Itē the watche must be kepte all nyghte, and the watche men
not departe, vntyll euery thynge be suere.

Item when the yates must be opened, there muste be so manye presente, as may wythstande the secrete assaute of theyre enemyes, for by thys meane Leystoure was taken, for whē .ii. or .iii. had opened the yates, theyre enemyes secretlye hydde, inuaded them and slewe them, and theire was treason wythin.
Item there muste be manye porters, for fewe maye be sone slayne by treason. &c.

Item yf any in the nyght season call to come in the whyche by name and voyce be knowen, that notwythstandynge, lye secrete espies let it be knowē, what nōber there be of thē & when yu openeste
the vtter gayte, see the innatre gayte shytte, for Frenche men by thys meane, toke Moelā, for .iiii. traytours fayned, that they had brought Inglyshe men from the bartaylle of sayncte Denys, they opened the gaytes, and were dysceyued,
Item manye men wyll consyder and counsayll dyuerse, and great thynges, to be attempted, be not swyfte to fololwe theyre counsaylle.
Item some be ignoraunt, and dreade no pareylle.
Item some wyll perswade, and counsaill greate thynges to be done, that they may be taken, and thoughte cowragyous, the whyche in effecte be of noo courage, Hi in bello extremi.

Item lette hym beware, that
none of hys hooste haue to great familyarytie wyth hys enemyes for feare of treason.

Item when he wyll battayle lette it be secretlye done, that the guyders knowe it not, and lette the gaytes be faste shytte before he cause men to putte them in armes, also let men be sette to kepe diligentelie the passages, oute of the cytie, that none may go vnto theyre enemyes to shewe the preparations that is made againste them, also when he shal come vnto the fylde wyth hys ennemyes to fyghte, lette hym take awaye contrary vnto that waye, whych myghte be thoughte he woulde take, and after he hathe gone .ii. or .iii. myles, in that waye, lette him returne vnto the way, which was fyrste thought, that he wold
haue takē, but let hym take good counsell hede, that neyther the guydes, nor other of hys company know whether he wyll goo vnto the tymethat they be in the feylde.
Item yf any of the carriages or guydes of the waynes come in to the towne let it be seene that, at theyre commynge in, one of the yares be shyte,

Item yf it fortune any of the sowldyers to be hurte, or wounded in battell or elles oute of the battel, lette the princes or theyr ministers see the medecine be minystred vnto them in dewe order lette them be visited and gentellye intreated with good and softe wordes, and let thē neyther lacke phesicyon nor surgyon for these sayde thinges do encourage and
nourishe the hartes of warryers, and make them stronge and wyllynge to fyght,

Item it behoueth a prince to make good serche and to knowe whyche of hys company be moste diligente valyaunte and taught in feates of warre, and of them make most and to nourishe them wyth great liberalyte accordyng to theyr merites, for the lyberalite of a prince causeth his companye to be diligent, and also multeplyeth and encreaseth the same
Itē it apperteyneth to a prince to forbydde that none of hys company entende conflycte or to goo oute of hys hooste wythoute lycence of theyre capytaynes.

Item many other thynges might be rehersed, wherby enemies myght be constrayned and repressed,
but take thys for a generall conclusyon, that the effecte of battayll consystethe and standeth in .iii. thynges, that is to say in the abundans of money, in good order putte and kepte, and in folowynge the counsayll and aduertisemēt of wyse and experte warryers.

div.head: ¶ To pacifye the sedition of sowldyours.
div.p:
VVan A. Manlius consule, hadde perceyued, that hys sowdiours grudged against the menne of Campania, where they were nowe lodged, conspyrynge togyther to slee theyr hostes, and after to take away their goodes, he spred abrode thys ruinour, that they shulde lye there
styl all the wynter, and thus they of theyr purpose let and dysturbed, he delyuered Campania frō greate perylle, and as tyme and occasion serued, punysshed them that were causers of that seditiō.

What tyme the legyons of the Romaynes were furyousely sente and bente on peryllous sedytion, Lucius Sylla restored them from theyr rage vnto a quietenes by thys polycie: He commaunded, that worde shulde be broughte hastely to the hooste, that theyr enemyes were at hande, and that they shoulde rayse vp a crye, and call them to harneys, and blowe vp the trumpettes, wherby he brake of the seditron, they all togyther cōsentyng as nede required, agaynste theyr enemyes.

What tyme Pompeius hoost hadde slayne the Senatoures of Millan, for feare of trouble and busynes, that myghte haue happened, yf he shoulde haue called the offenders alone to examination, he sente for them all togyther, as well for the fautlesse, as the gyltie, so that they semed to be sēt for, for some other purpose and therfore appered they that were fautye, wyth lesse feare, bycause they came not alone: and they, whose consciēce pleded them not gyltye, gaue good attendaunce, to kepe them that were fautie, lest peraduenture their escape and flyght, myght haue tourned thē to displeasure.
